importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the conclusion of the National League Championship Series (NLCS) and the beginning of the anticipation for the 2025 World Series, where the Los Angeles Dodgers will face the American League champion.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of the postseason culminates on this date with the Dodgers sweeping the Milwaukee Brewers in four games, setting the stage for the World Series and marking a historic moment in team and individual performance.

keyTakeAways: Shohei Ohtani delivered one of the most extraordinary performances in MLB history, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters in a single game during the NLCS.
Ohtani became the first starting pitcher since 1900 to hit multiple home runs in a postseason game and the first since 1900 to hit a leadoff home run in the playoffs.
The performance occurred after Ohtani pitched in a game just 13 days prior, making it the first time a starting pitcher had pitched that short a span.
Ohtani achieved the first instance in MLB history of hitting three home runs and striking out at least one batter, let alone 10.
The Dodgers swept the Milwaukee Brewers in the NLCS, advancing to the World Series for the first time in the past nine seasons.
This marks the fifth time in the last nine seasons that the Dodgers have won the National League pennant and the 26th time in franchise history they have reached the World Series.
The Dodgers have not lost a game in the postseason since the NLDS loss to the Phillies, and their pitching staff, including Ohtani, has remained dominant.
Ohtani was named NLCS MVP and was described by teammates as having performed at a level that will likely be remembered as 'the Shohei Ohtani Game'.

namedEntities.name: Shohei Ohtani
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Japanese professional baseball player and two-way superstar (pitcher and hitter)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ohtani’s historic performance in the NLCS, including three home runs and a 10-strikeout game, is the central event of the article and represents a milestone in MLB history, making him a globally recognized figure in sports.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Major League Baseball team based in Los Angeles, California
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers are the team that advanced to the World Series after sweeping the Milwaukee Brewers in the NLCS, showcasing their dominance and reinforcing their status as a powerhouse franchise.

namedEntities.name: Milwaukee Brewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Major League Baseball team based in Milwaukee, Wisconsin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Brewers were the opponents in the NLCS, and the Dodgers' four-game sweep signifies a major postseason victory and marks the end of their playoff run.

namedEntities.name: National League Championship Series (NLCS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Postseason series determining the National League representative for the World Series
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The NLCS is the pivotal series that led to the Dodgers' advancement to the World Series, highlighting the significance of the matchup and Ohtani’s performance.

namedEntities.name: World Series
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Annual championship series in Major League Baseball between the American and National League champions
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers’ NLCS victory sets them up to face the American League champion in the World Series, marking a major milestone in their 2025 postseason run.

namedEntities.name: Clayton Kershaw
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former MLB pitcher and future Hall of Famer with the Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kershaw praises Ohtani’s performance and acknowledges the team’s dominance, adding credibility to the narrative of the Dodgers’ success and Ohtani’s impact.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Freeman provides a teammate's perspective on Ohtani’s performance, emphasizing the team effort and the historic nature of the game.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays are the opposing team in the ALCS against the Mariners, establishing the context for the eventual World Series opponent.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Roberts comments on the team’s success and the broader significance of the Dodgers' postseason run, tying the achievement to the team's legacy and future goals.

namedEntities.name: Sarah Langs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Langs provides statistical validation of Ohtani’s historic performance, adding expert credibility to the claims of uniqueness in MLB history.

namedEntities.name: TNT Sports
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: TNT Sports broadcast the game and reported on Ohtani’s performance, including the historic milestone of a starting pitcher hitting multiple home runs in a postseason game.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic performance in the National League Championship Series, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters in a single game while pitching in a 13-day span—making him the first starting pitcher since 1900 to hit multiple home runs in a postseason game and the first to hit a leadoff home run in the playoffs. His performance led the Los Angeles Dodgers to a four-game sweep of the Milwaukee Brewers and secured their spot in the 2025 World Series. Ohtani was named NLCS MVP, and the victory marked the fifth time in the last nine seasons that the Dodgers have won the NL pennant. The article highlights the significance of this achievement not only for the team but also for the global recognition of Ohtani as a transformative figure in baseball history.
title: Shohei Ohtani’s legendary night leads Los Angeles Dodgers to another World Series, sweeping Milwaukee in 4 games
